sect1.title: Using the GNOME &nm; Applet
sect1.para: In GNOME, &nm; can be controlled with the GNOME &nm; applet. If the network is set up for &nm; control, the applet usually starts automatically with the desktop environment and is shown as an icon in the system tray.
If your system tray does not show any network connection icon, the applet is probably not started. Press F2 and enter nm-applet to start it manually.

sect2.title: Managing Wired Network Connections
sect2.para: If your computer is connected to an existing network with a network cable, use the &nm; applet to choose the network connection.

step.para: Left-click the applet icon to show a menu with available networks. The currently used connection is selected in the menu.
To switch to another network, choose it from the list.
To switch off all network connections, both wired and wireless, right-click the applet icon and deactivate Enable Networking.

sect2.title: Managing Wireless Network Connections
sect2.para: Available visible wireless networks are listed in the GNOME &nm; applet menu under Wireless Networks. The signal strength of each network is also shown in the menu. Encrypted wireless networks are marked with a shield icon.

step.para: To connect to a wireless network, left-click the applet icon and select an entry from the list of available wireless networks.

If the network is encrypted, a dialog opens. It shows the type of encryption the network uses (Wireless Security) and holds a number of text boxes according to the respective encryption and authentication settings. Enter the appropriate credentials.

To connect to a network that does not broadcast its service set identifier (SSID or ESSID) and therefore cannot be detected automatically, left-click the &nm; icon and choose Connect to Hidden Wireless Network.
In the dialog that opens, enter the SSID or ESSID in Network Name and set encryption parameters if necessary.

To disable wireless networking, right-click the applet icon and deactivate Enable Wireless. This can be useful if you are on a plane or in any other environment where wireless networking is not allowed.

sect2.para: A wireless network that has been chosen explicitly will remain connected as long as possible. If a network cable is plugged in during that time, any connections that have been set to Stay connected when possible will be connected, while the wireless connection remains up.

sect2.title: Configuring Your Wi-Fi/Bluetooth Card as an Access Point
sect2.para: If your Wi-Fi/Bluetooth card supports access point mode, you can use &nm; for configuration.

note.title: Availability of Options
note.para: Depending on your system setup, you may not be allowed to configure connections. In a secured environment, some options might be locked or require &rootuser; permission. Ask your system administrator for details.

step.para: Click the &nm; applet and select Create New Wireless Network.
Enter a Network Name and set the encryption to use with the Wireless Security drop-down box.

important.title: Unprotected Wireless Networks Are a Security Risk
important.para: If you set Wireless Security to None, everybody can connect to your network, reuse your connectivity and intercept your network connection. To restrict access to your access point and to secure your connection, use encryption. You can choose between various WEP and WPA–based encryption.
